description.text:
A simple holder for square notes paper slips. An attempt was made to create a shape that would minimize the amount of material required and printing time, and still provide a rigid enough framework for the paper notes. Will take approximately 5-6 hours to print at fine quality (0.1 mm, 30-50 mm/s) and require 25 grams of filament. If you need a different size or want your own text on it just let me know and I will gladly design it and upload it here at no charge. title: LED fixture for Replicator, CTC, Flashforge

description.text:
I designed this bracket to mount into the front corner of my CTC 3D printer using 3M double sided tape. It is designed to sit in the corner and create a 45* flat section to which a12V LED strip was attached.I wired the two LED strips in series so that my 24V power supply could run them without any sort of step-down transformer or a wall wort. I like my installs to be clean. I wired it directly to two of the screw terminals on my power supply that weren't being used and then drilled a hole in the faceplate of my printer to fit a 3/4" rocker switch.   
Goodbye days of hovering over my printer with a flashlight!

description.text:
A quick and dirty sketch of a python clone of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6955 Takes a function of x,y,r, and t (theta, in radians), plots it, returns it as a solid which it spits to stdout, or writes to a .scad or .stl file, depending on usage. Arguments are set toward the top of the scrip. The function is specified as a string. This script requires numpy. Comments need improvement. Python seems popular, so I'm hoping this will be stolen and modified. There are probably still bugs in the mesh generation, I haven't even tried slicing the test object. If you spot a fix, tell me (or post a fix as your own thing). update : fixed generation of base polygons
update : fixed normal orientation for .scad and .stl output
update : fixed scaling issues, now scales part to the intended dimensions
update : fixed some command line argument parsing
update : OpenSCAD doesn't like the .stl output, but the .scad script output seems ok. Probably some problem with specifying the normals.

( for mac / linux, I don't know how python works on Windows )
I call it like so : python surf2solid.py > test.stl python surf2solid.py test.stl
python surf2solid.py test.scad ./surf2solid.py output.stl surf2solid output.stl

remixed_from.author: alextoff
remixed_from.title: Dual E3D V6 - Independently Height Adjustable Mount for Rostock Max V2

title: Dual E3D V6, Independently Height Adjustable Mount for Rostock Max V2 - Locknut Mod

description.text:
Modified E3D Dual Mount for the RoStock MAX V2; includes head clearance for all three M3 SHCS to mount/adjust 2nd extruder.  Also reworked "Mount 2" to include clearance for M3 nylocks.  
I'm thinking I'll do a V3 that incorporates M3 or 6-32 helicoils directly into the part.  
V2 parts have now been netfabbed.

Printed in solid ABS. Assembly is a bit wonky:

  • Mount 1 above the platform; Extruder 1 below; Extruder 1 mounted in its groove on Mount 1

  • Mount 1 w/ Extruder 1 located on platform but not attached

  • Locknuts loaded into Mount 2_V2; Extruder 2 mounted in its groove on Mount 2_V2

  • Mount 2 w/ Extruder 2 brought up from underside of platform

  • Lots of wiggling and alignment until top surfaces of Mount 1 and Mount 2 are coplanar and Mounts are located on/in platform

  • Load screws into Top; thread screws into Mount 2_V2 locknuts; tighten sequentially to maintain reasonable parallelism between Top and Mounts until Top contacts Mounts

  • Run 6-32 hardware from underside of platform to secure assembly to platform.

  • Adjust height of Extruder 2 to match Extruder 1

  • Do the 6,000 other things you have to do to get your RoStock MAX V2 to run dual extruders...

comments.text: The fixed versions are closer; the non-manifold vertices are gone anyway.  It looks like something in the process changed the scale of the part, slic3r is reporting it to be 1000 times larger than the original (units issue, m vs mm?), so it was running out of ram generating the tool paths for a part that size.  Unfortunately slic3r's ability to scale parts is limited to integer values, so I can't put in .1%, but when I'm home from work this evening with more time to tinker, I'll try scaling it down in something else and see if that works.
comments.author: wcarver1

comments.text: I'm having no issue scaling to 0.001 which converts the meters of the part file to millimeters. In short, when I remix a file from STL format, SW brings it in with units of meters regardless of the original file units.  If the file is then modified and scaled, not all the vertices scale with the modifications so I tend to leave units as meters and export to STL, then scale by 0.001 prior to slicing.
comments.author: gravatite

comments.text: Slic3r does a nice job at slicing, but it's pretty limited at manipulation.  That said, I pulled it into meshlab real quick and it scaled down nicely there, and it looks great in slic3r now.  Thanks for your help!

This is a remix of Crispy001's "FreeTrack 3 Point Hat Model".  
I found it would take about 2hrs to build the original design and it would possibly require supports. I've made some alterations to the model to allow it to be easily printed in two parts without supports, as well as reducing the print time to around 30mins (when done at 0.3).  
Additionally I've added some grooves where the wires can sit in and also tunneled a path inside the L piece for the wires to go up to the top LED. Then threw in a bit of hot glue just to hold the wires in place, it doesn't have to look pretty, it just has to work!  
I tip my hat to Crispy001 for his original design.

This has been designed so you can feed the wires through the L piece to the two front left & right LEDs. You should be able to push the wires through to help keep the cables neat and tidy. I would recommend dropping a dab of hot glue in the hole before inserting the L piece to keep it from separating later. I would recommend viewing this link below to see what LEDs & Resistors you will need as IR LEDS tend to vary in volts/amps/etc.
http://www.free-track.net/english/hardware/calcled If you have any questions, feel free to drop me a message. ~ iTrooper

This is a replacement globe for ceiling fan light fixture.  It is about 11" wide and the center section is about 4".  
My printer can't quite handle 11" diameter, so the model is split three pieces.

The model is designed for printing in Spiral mode. I printed it on my Rostock Max v2 using a 0.4mm nozzle with 0.8mm thickness, 0.2mm layers at 60mm/s. If you printer is capable of printing the part in one piece, you can comment out the line in the scad file which splits it up. If you are assembling from three prints:
  • Each piece will print with two unwanted walls. Use something (scissors work well) to cut those out (see the photos).
  • Break out some of the central post. Leave about an inch.
  • Glue the three pieces together. Since I printed in ABS, I used acetone as glue. This is rather annoying since acetone is hard to control. A thicker glue would be less of a pain.

title: Filament Width Sensor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a prototype for a sensor that is intended to measure the width of plastic filament in real time as it goes into a 3d printing extruder. It is a proof of concept. The idea is that with a real-time width measurement the 3D printer could compensate the extruded flow for changes in filament width. Prototype #2 is in progress, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:89044

Principle of operation: An LED with a narrow field of view is used to illuminate the filament. A shadow of the filament is projected onto a linear sensor array (400 pixels/inch). An 8 bit processor is used to detect the edges of the shadow image and calculate the width. The image sample and width measurement occurs every .1 sec. The filament in the sensor is around 2.85mm. The picture of the screen shows a debug view of the processor measuring it as widthmm=28575 (2.8575). The sensor has some variability depending on how close the filament is to the linear sensor array, but it is surprisingly small (1-2 pixels, or .06-.12 mm). The case is designed with two notches to hold the filament in place. Some improvements needed:
  • a better approach is needed to handle keeping the moving filament in a stationary view.
  • filtering of the width measurement
  • a light-proof case
  • Suitable interface to 3D printer controller (a Printrboard in my case)
    • The line sensor board is a modified version of one I found here. https://github.com/kbellve/TSL1401CL-Adapter I modified it to be completely single sided surface mount so that I could mill it more easily to make a quick prototype.

comments.text: Cool sensor
comments.author: thunderbug

comments.text: It should be as simple as possible, but not simpler.
comments.author: thunderbug

comments.text: I agree with Leorex that an LDR might require more complicated calibration and be sensitive to the color or type of filament.  Maybe even variation of color in a filament.  Also, LDR sensors like a CDS cell have variability in output from sensor to sensor, so it might be hard to make this approach repeatable.  Photodiodes have less variability, so if the color calibration issues can be overcome, it might work.
comments.author: SirGeekALot

comments.text: Excellent start and some great comments! I too had devoted some thought regarding how to measure the filament flow in real time, and I had considered gutting an old laser mouse mouse for this purpose but dismissed it because (as pointed out in the comments) it probably would only get linear distance and not width (which is considerably more important).
comments.author: SirGeekALot

comments.text: My current thought is to use a single sensor and have it scan the filament over an arc of 90 degrees using an RC servo.  The microcontroller would control the RC servo's position and then integrate the width measurement at various angles to get a cross sectional area.  This way a true cross sectional area could be measured.  The scan would occur over a couple seconds, and the filament would be traversing into the extruder , so this approach would have a limitation of detecting variations that occur over a couple cm of the length of the filament.  My sense is that the variation of cross-section of the filament along its length occurs over intervals of many cm, so this approach would work.  It is still an improvement over measuring with a caliper in a few locations at the start of a print run.  Mechanically the filament itself would be used as a shaft that the sensor rotates around.  There would be a gear on it, and one on the RC servo and with the correct gear ratio a scan of 90 degrees would be achieved.   Other drawbacks are the mechanical complexity and higher risk of mechanical failure and interaction effects between the motion of the sensor and the width sensing approach (vibration, etc).  These could be reduced by scanning slowly, but at the expense of sensitivity to fast variations of cross-sectional area.
comments.author: SirGeekALot

comments.text: Creative thinking!!!
comments.author: LeftAngle

comments.text: I could imagine using the electronics from two micrometers and measuring the width using a pair of spring-loaded ball bearings along one axis, and (for a more meaningful value) another pair perpendicular to the first. Take the average of the two measurements. If you can do the same thing optically, great.
comments.author: thinkyhead

comments.text: I could imagine using the electronics from two micrometers and measuring the width using a pair of spring-loaded ball bearings along one axis, and (for a more meaningful value) another pair perpendicular to the first. Take the average of the two measurements. If you can do the same thing optically, great.
comments.author: thinkyhead

comments.text: If you place a lens between the LED and the filament that collimates the light it should be far more insensitiv for the longitudinal displacement of the filament since the sensitivity for the displacement comes from the divergence of the light from the LED.
comments.author: goaran

comments.text: Yes, that would help, but it would also add another component with addl complexity to the design.  An alternative is to find an LED with a better built-in lens.   I have found some LED's at mouser that have 4 deg field of view, so that should help some.  The current prototype has a surplus LED from my parts bin so I don't have any specs on it, but I think it's wider than 4 deg.
comments.author: goaran

comments.text: An optical mouse sensor would work for feed rate, but it might not have the resolution to measure width.  I've seen optical mouse "video" and I think it is only 16 or 32 pixels wide.
comments.author: ianjohnson

comments.text: Yes, maintaining alignment while the filament is travelling is critical, but it didn't seem as critical as I first thought .  I was able to move the filament 1 mm or so back and forth from the sensor and still get a good measurement.  So a PTFE tube might work for maintaining alignment.  My initial thought was two small bearings, one fixed and one with spring tension to hold the filament at a fixed reference.   A laser approach would get better resolution, but I was going for a low cost approach.  Finding a sensor array with higher resolution would work (1024 pixels/inch), but so far I have not been able to find one.
comments.author: ianjohnson

comments.text:
Wouldnt it be easier to use sensor&electronics from optical mouse?
It has everything in...
comments.author: zdar

comments.text: Perfect -- will be extremely useful for quality control for recycled filament running through recyclebots or for processing functional materials through any filament extruder system like the Lyman. Nice start!
comments.author: jpearce

comments.text: This is a good start, but measuring the filament in a single direction isn't enough.  Often filament becomes more oval than round, especially if it has been tightly wound on the spool and then left in a hot place (UPS truck?).  It is possible that you could measure it abnormally wide or narrow when it is actually more normal.  It would also be nice if you could detect if the filament has ran out, and sound an alarm.  That's just a simple firmware mod.
comments.author: david49152

comments.text: Current idea is to use two led-sensor pairs at 90 degrees of each other.  They would be identical in every regard.  Getting two shadows to appear with mirrors or LED's at 45 degree angles on one sensor seems like it is very dependent on getting the position of the filament just right and optic alighment.  The sensors are cheap, and this way the design is reused.
comments.author: david49152

comments.text: I have an idea to measure it in two directions: Place a second LED pointing in a right angle to the first one, also directed towards the filament. Place a mirror behind it, which projects a second shadow on the sensor. If the sensor is large enough and the mirror is placed accordingly, it should be possible to measure both shadows on one sensor. If it is an RGB sensor, use different colors so the shadows can overlap. This is just a first idea.
comments.author: david49152

comments.text: If you were doing 1.75 mm filament then you could use two LED's at 90 deg to each other, but both LED's are 45 deg to a single sensor.  No mirror.  Then you alternately turn on one LED, then the next, to measure X and Y.  The sensor you are using right now is too short to do this with 3 mm filament, but you can still use the alternating LED idea with a mirror so you don't have to deal with an RGB sensor.
comments.author: leemes

comments.text: Yeah of course! Now as you say it: I think the best would be to let the filament go directly in front of the sensor, so the shadow footprint is as small as possible. For a 3mm filament, it's just a bit more than 6mm if two LEDs are placed in +- 45 degrees. If this is still to large, +- 30 degrees should provide good results, too. I don't know how big the sensor is which the author uses (I'm not the author of the thing).
comments.author: david49152

comments.text: If the shadow is small, there are fewer pixels representing the diameter, so it would take a bigger change in size to trigger the next pixel.  A wider shadow will allow more precise measurement.  The edge might be fuzzier, but you could include a bias setting to decide what shade of grey will be considered "shaded".
comments.author: leemes

comments.text: Nice, this may be also useful for filament extruders like Lyman or Filastruder.

description.text: When I made a copy of the neat game Cyvasse by dutchmogul over at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:92172, I thought it could really use a proper box to go into. So naturally I decided to print one! This box features shaped slots for the large pieces to fit into, separate bins for the white and black small pieces, and is properly sized to snugly fit the board and wall sections. The lid slides into place and has the game's name debossed into the surface. Play on!

While the top portion of the lid nominally has a width of 137.3 mm, when printed mine shrank down to 136.8 mm. This lead to a slightly looser fit than originally designed, though it still works perfectly fine. If you want a tighter fit however, I recommend scaling up the lid in the horizontal dimensions just ever so slightly. I have left the models as is however, in case people want to print in materials with less shrinkage.  
Printed in PLA/PHA, 0.2 mm layer height, 230 C, 50 mm/s, 25% infill.

title: Replacement Output Flap for Dell 1110 Laser Printer

description.text: The company for which I work has old Dell 1110 Laser Printers on almost every desk in the company.  As far as I can tell, their biggest flaw is that these little plastic flaps which push the paper down after it's printed and clear the output area for the next sheet, constantly break and cause a mess of paper collisions.  So after being tired of cleaning up the sheets which got pushed onto the floor and under the desk, I quickly drew up a replacement part that would be printable on my Thing-O-Matic.

My first attempt was ok, but I need to slow down the feed rate to increase the detail (i.e. density & strength) of the two thin arms.  Also, the cylindrical tabs which hold the piece in and allow for rotation look to be problematic and will require some sanding.  Other than that, it printed quite well, and perfectly to scale.

author: Alghoul

description.text:
Small drawers for all your little storage needs. Drawer case- 97 tall, 75 wide and 100mm front to back.
Drawer big bin size- 33.5 X 46 and 20mm deep.
Drawer small bin size- 33.5 X 22.25 and 20mm deep 8-2-15 Added 2 bin and 1 bin versions.
2-29-16 I'm releasing the Sketchup file so anyone can mod, enjoy.

If the drawer locks too well in the closed position sand the bottom front face of the drawer below the handle.
If printing without a heated bed or without good bed adhesion use the anti warp versions of drawers.
A no top version of the drawer frame is included for stacking and reduced plastic usage of the lower segments.
Model tolerances tuned with the expectation of 0.2mm layer heights, if thicker the drawers may not slide well.
A average print cooling system is need to help with the minor bridging and stringing reduction. Some tuning of the slicer settings may be need to get the thin walls to print without vertical gaps in the filament paths. I had the most luck with only 1 perimeter and 10% infill. Take your time to inspect the tool path before printing.
Slic3r slicer used on a Replicator2 with PLA plastic.

comments.text: Nice job, this a very good and useful print. I would like to have a 2 bins drawer divided in the other side (horizontally). Thanks.
comments.author: Toley

comments.text:
Hey, I really like the design. I was amazed home well the main part printed. I thought the last line across the top was going to fail because of the lack of support but it worked beautifully. The problem I had later was that the drawers wouldn't fit in. I only printed one and I tried filing it down and trimming/beveling edges with a Stanley knife.
I printed again at 98% width and 97% height. and it worked perfectly.
I imagine the issue is probably just that my settings aren't 100% perfect and the minor imperfections stopped it fitting.
Either way, I've got 2 out of 4 drawers done now and I'll post some pics when I have the rest done.

Good to hear you got the layer issue sorted. 102% might be a bit much perhaps 101% or so is a better idea. Let me know how it turns out.
Also I recommend 0.2 layer heights or less, the thicker the layers the more the extrusion line squashes past the expected edge of the model causing fit issues.

title: Headphone Cord Wrap #1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is the first of several experiments I have made to build a cord wrap for my Etymotic headphones. They are a little unique in that the cords are fairly large for such small headphones. I tried three different thicknesses (scale Z only) and liked the original thin one the best of this design. The middle one was scaled in Z by 1.5. The larger one was scaled 2.5 in Z. They are printed in Red Soft PLA which gives them flexibility to allow the cord to easily be squeezed into the slots and allow some bend in the whole thing. Not exactly your style? See Headphone Cord Wrap #2 and Cord Wrap #3.

This is a spool hub designed to have a 608Z bearing press fit into the inside hole.  Two of these hubs are then put onto an M8 rod, and then bolted in place to hold in an ABS spool.  You can manipulate the file to suit your own spool sizes.  My spools happened to have a 45mm hole in the middle.  As you can see below, this assembly is then being suspended by the frame(carcass?) of my old Mendel.
The bottom edge of the inside hole and the top edge of the outer cylinder have a 2.5mm fillet to make it easier to press in the bearing, as well as insert into the spool.

This was a very straightforward print and required almost no post-processing cleanup.  Simply place your bearing on a flat, solid surface, and gently press down on the spool hub until it is securely in place.

The White Stripe is an interactive light made out of 5 elements that fit together. The lamp can be combined freely and you can produce as many modules as you want or need.   
The modules are hold together by magnets which are also used to transport electricity. Watch out, that you don't touch the magnets while the light is on and don't mix up the plus and minus pole (are marked on the frame).  
You need basic knowledge in electronics to produce the electronics and the LED-stuff.

The White Stripe is made with a laser cutter. You need:
  • 3 mm ply wood
  • 16 magnets (10 x 10 x 1 mm)
  • 16 pieces of iron (17 x 11 x 1 mm)
  • 1 electronic converter with 12 volt
  • 1 on/off switch
  • 1 meter cuttable white LED-stripe
  • thin paper
    • First cut out the frames with a laser cutter, then grind 45° or 60° angles in the edges. After paint it in a color you like, and stick the thin paper on the inside of the frames. Then glue the magnets and the pieces of iron on the outside of the frames. Take care of the polarity of the magnet! Cut out the LED-stripe construction, put it together and glue it. Glue the LED-stripes on the edge of the construction, then connect the LEDs with the magnets. The last step is gluing the single frames together. Maybe the following video could help you to build The White Stripe: https://vimeo.com/121157356

I ordered a couple of ColorFab sample kits and had to come up with something that would hold the material for printing.  This is a simple design that is easy to print.  This part is designed as a push fit but I used super glue to secure the arms into the hub.  
As this spool has very little weight there is a chance that the filament will cause the spool to spin and unwind.  I prevent this by pushing some kitchen paper inside the hub.  This increases the friction between the hub and what ever it it mounted on and stops the "free" spinning.  
One thing I would change is to only glue 3 of the arms into place.  This would allow the 4th arm to be removed and then the material would be removed from the spool easier.

As much as I love OpenSCAD, constructive solid geometry is just not efficient at certain tasks and I got tired of waiting for hundreds of spheres to be unioned and rendered to make a knot.  This is a parametric Matlab script to do the same thing as MakeALot's script, but in seconds instead of hours, plus the mesh is smoother.  
The [3,1] knot I printed required more material for support than the print did, but it came out nice in the end.  I designed it to fit a 12.7mm steel ball I had extras of from a Geomag set.  Since the knot is toroidal, the ball freely rolls around the inside without falling out.
I included a couple of other example knot STLs in case you can't run the script.

Run VarKnot.m in Matlab (or Octave, which hopefully should also work) and adjust the commented parameters at the beginning of the file as desired.  It uses surf2stl.m, which I included because I made some adjustments from the version available on the Matlab file exchange.  There don't appear to be any license conflicts, and hopefully my changes will show up there soon too.  Basically I added the ability to export multiple objects in a single STL, which is what you get with the [2,4] knot, for instance.
There is a vertical stretch parameter that allows the knot to be taller (to make supportless printing possible) while maintaining the circular cross-section.  There is also a thickness parameter that flattens the bottom of the STL to make a base area where the print can actually stick to the build platform.  
The one lame thing about scripting this versus the OpenSCAD version, is there's no guarantee your mesh will be manifold.  Basically you have to look at the plot and adjust the parameters so that it doesn't self-intersect.

comments.text: Thank you for sharing your matlab script files. They also ran with octave too!
comments.author: joachim67

comments.text: Just to avoid some confusion, the "[p,q] knot" notation used here indicates either a "(p,q) torus knot", or a "(p,q) torus link", depending on the co-primality of p and q. Thus "[3,1] knot" = "unknot", then "[2,5] knot" = "knot 5_1", and "[2,4] knot" = "link of 2 components with linking nuber 2".

Update (4/5/2016) -- Leaving this in the car with direct sunlight is not good on hot days. The part can warp beyond practical use. I'd advise against PLA for this reason. I've printed it in ABS and the car is in covered parking (in Texas up to 100+) and has still been fine. So the direct sunlight with PLA is a bad option in summer. Never had a problem with PLA in cooler seasons.
Designed these two mounts to slide into my car's CD tray in order to hold my iPhone 6 & iPhone6+. The iPhone6 version has been designed around the Otterbox Commuter case. The phone drops in with no added effort. The design allows it to be plugged in while mounted. I've uploaded the NX CAD files so you can customize it to fit your case.  
Just a heads up -- depending on what material you use, keep an eye on it this summer. My phone is getting a little more snug after the car has been sitting outside all day due to the PLA expanding. I designed/ built this over winter so I don't know how well it'll hold up over summer.

description.text:
An extending tube printed as a single print.
Extend, twist and push to lock in place.

Print, extend, twist and push to lock in place. If you downloaded the tapered versions don't print them!
Download a new version (TaperedExtendingTube1), I forgot to taper the center tube so it will be joined to the next tube - sorry about that! I wanted to test how closely I could put moving parts as one print and still move them without lots of cutting afterwards. This design worked without any cleaning up, (apart from removing the raft) Not too functional as is, but I expect to use the principles from this in other projects. In the SCAD file, you'll find one main module:
tube(tubeOuterRadius, tubeHeight, tubeCount, extend); tubeOuterRadius = either 40,35,30,25 or 20
tubeHeight = the height in mm (between 30 and 90)
tubeCount = the number of tubes (1-6 depending on radius)
extend = 1 to show extended, 0 for printing The center tube stays quite mobile during the print due to its inability to cool within the mass of the print, so it may be difficult to print a very small inner tube. Hope this proves useful in mashups! Update:
Added a tapered version as suggested by Zomboe (thanks Zomboe) this simplifies the locking mechanism. I haven't printed this yet.

description.text:
If you add a glass bed on top of your Dreamer's aluminum build plate, you will need to lower the z-axis so that the nozzles don't crash into the glass.  
Based on salbemerson's  Creator Pro shim, this thing is specifically designed for the FlashForge Dreamer and a 1/4-inch (6.35mm) piece of glass. It is a snug fit so no double-sided tape or glue is needed to hold it in place.  
To install, you need to remove the plastic Flashforge logo plate, which is held in place with two screws. Then place the shim on the edge of the metal lip as shown.

author: TayRowell

description.text: Organize your botspace with this modular set of parts to build shelving and tool holders for the TOM. (My first Thing!) There are two shelf modules here -- a closed-ended and an open-ended design, and two lengths of brackets. Pics show all of these in use. This system of parts works on the same clip principle as Thing 6951, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6951 but I've been working on these parts independently for a couple of months (since I first got my TOM), so it's an example of "convergent evolution" rather than derivation, I think.

With the exception of the brackets and clips, all parts have to be mirrored to create full sets (i.e. there will be a left and right half when you're done, but the .stl files are just "single-handed;" mirror them appropriately in RepG to make the two sides of the shelves and tool holders.  The two halves of the tool holders have to be super-glued together.

author: shakulin1998

description.text:
I designed my own truss system :-)
A section is about 25 cm in height, and the heart-to-heart distance between 2 outer poles is 15 cm.
You need long pieces of rod, 10mm diameter.
Yellow pieces can be connected with M3 bolts/nuts ... I'm using this system for my homebuilt large RGB LED matrix. (2m x 1m20, so 320 x 192 pixels) I still need to draw the corner pieces. Give me some time to finish this :-)

• I use pieces of 2 meter 10mm hollow aluminium rod.
  • you need 6 M3 bolts/nuts to connect to sections together.
  • Cut 3x 26,5 cm rod for the diagonal parts.
  • leave the 3 vertical rods in one piece, just slide your sections over it.
  • Use 2 identical parts for every section.
  • Alternate between regular and mirror part for every section.

comments.text: Thanks for posting!  I look forward to the corner pieces.

It's a spool roller with the exact same design as Airtripper's Pocket Filament Reel Rollers, but that uses half the bearings. All credit to Airtripper for this fantastic and useful design! Update April 7
The description said that a piece needed to be mirrored, but it doesn't. To use this thing you must print 4 identical pieces.

To make a pair of reel rollers you need to print 4 of the roller pieces. This is to ensure the hole that the roller has in the base is in oposite sides, so a screw can be placed. Parts List: 4 x 608 ZZ (or simply 608) Roller Skate Ball Bearings. Very cheap off Ebay.
8 x M3 x 20mm Hex Head Screws. Ebay.
16 x M3 washers. Ebay.
8 x M3 Nuts. Ebay.
3D Printer Filament. Tools Required 3D Printer.
Hex Key to Fit Screw Heads.
Pliers or Spanner of some type.
3MM drill bit (or 3.2 so the screw can go through easier) to clean out the screw holes in the printed parts.

description.text:
Picture the scene: YOUR HOUSE, 30MINS BEFORE DEPARTURE
"That's weird, I was sure my cufflinks were right where I always leave them..." Disaster has struck, you've got half an hour before you need to be out of the house, and you cannot, for love nor money, find your cufflinks. It's not as if you need them to be particularly flashy - just hold your darned sleeves closed! Well worry no more, these small, basic, temporary cufflinks have you covered. Quick to print, subdued and functional.

I've only tested these when printed with a raft - my instincts suggest that raftless printing would be a disaster.
Print these in pairs, one after the other.  
DO let them cool a little before removing them from the printing surface - they are delicate and will bend.
Remove the raft using a sharp knife, being careful not to cut through the cufflink sides.
These are bendy, but haven't broken yet.  Turn the cufflink so the flat side of the partial circle faces the wrist, so they 'lock' in place and won't fall out.
Please Note - They are temporary, emergency cufflinks.  They take about half an hour to print two of them, and they use less than 1 gram of ABS each.

A soda Caddy for the standard 12 Pack boxes of soda. Made for a standard 12 FL OZ aluminum can. Made in multiple parts that should print on any printer with a build area capable of printing 6" x 4" (152.4mm x 101.6mm). Will need gluing once printed. I have a large format version which prints the entire setup at 8" x 18" if you have a printer that can print that big (zipped File). Again this is not tested but it should be good as a soda can is fairly standard now.

Print one of each part except the part labeled wall peg. You'll need 22 of these if you use them to assist in lining up the walls. To assemble the walls you'll need to glue the parts together (no tabs so a flat surface will be needed). There are lines on the individual pieces. These lines line up on adjacent parts. If you use the Wall_Peg.stl you'll need to apply glue to the edges of the wall part and then to the wall peg itself and inset it into the grooves on each part. This should give it some strength in the walls. All the R parts are for the Right wall and the L parts are for the Left wall. Match the lines up.   
The ramps and the back piece has slots built into them that match up to the tabs on the wall parts. apply a small amount of glue to the slots and then insert the tabs from the corresponding pieces. Once everything is together, give ample time to dry and then it should be usable.

author: axiotron

title: Universal Case Generator with Example Case for Cubieboard

description.text: This thing is still "work in progress" and will be updated every now and then. So please collect or follow this thing instead of just downloading it to receive updates! Note: This thing is only the output of an automatic model generator.

This is a new project: a 3D-printable case model generator written in C++ and the powerful C++ object oriented mechanics library OOML. Create a case model for any electronic's board with minimal effort: the generator includes an algorithm (the actual, generic design), instead of a design for a particular device. The generator outputs the model as a SCAD file, which can then be further processed to an STL file by OpenSCAD and finally 3D-printed. This thing contains a case for the CubieBoard only as an example. (However, it isn't finished yet: a slot for the SD card as well as a hole for the IR sensor are missing). To generate a case for a new device, you simply describe the board, such as the CubieBoard, Raspberry Pi, Arduino, etc. (the dimensions, holes and ports). No further effort needed, unless you want some special things on your case or the result isn't as expected. Then just run the generator on your new "board description". For the source code of the generator itself, clone the git repository at https://bitbucket.org/leemes/ooml-case-factory. Or use this direct download link (.zip). This is a program written in C++, so you need a C++ compiler (which supports C++11), such as g++ (under Windows, it's called mingw). You also have to install ooml (see link above). When successfully compiled, you simply have to run the executable. There will be 3 files created (as uploaded in this thing): one file with both parts as well as two files with the parts separately. Open the files in OpenSCAD, render, export as STL and finally print. If you'd like to build a case for a new board, please let me know in the comments! Also if you want to customize the design generation algorithm. I can help you as well as you can contribute to the project. Some documentation and instructions for the internal workings to make it easy to create new board descriptions will follow. Also, I might create some online editor which lets you download the final SCAD file directly within the browser. Someone wants to help?

I printed it in ABS with 0.2mm layer height, 30% fill, no support.  
The only tricky thing is printing the bridge at the screws of the smaller part: The screw heads will fit in some cuboid-shaped holes (you don't see them from this perspective, they are at the bottom). At the layer when these holes should be closed (the screw head ends), there is still the hole for the screw thread. Printing such a "bridge with a hole" is nearly impossible. For this, the generator inserts a "safe bridge": two to three additional layers without a hole for the screw thread (entire bridges). Drilling them out by hand should be easily possible.

• Make sure the holes for the screws are large enough: Drill the hole at the bottom part (the smaller one) so an M3 screw can slide through (remove the "safe bridge" as explained above). You might want to screw down the assembled case first without a board to safely apply larger forces without damaging your board.

  • Put the Cubieboard upside down in the top part (the bigger one), the Ethernet port ahead. Its springs on the side have to "slide" in the whole for the port.

  • Important: After putting it in the top part, make sure the board's bottom surface (the one facing at you right now) is level with the inner half of the wall. This is the level where the bottom part will press against the board. If you don't make sure it's level, your board can be damaged!

  • Put the bottom part on top of the top part. It should close almost gapless without much force. If not, make sure the board fits correct and have a look for the location of the blocking.

  • Put four M3 screws with length between 8mm and 25mm (1in) (for example, these can be the same type than the ones you use for your printer's stepper motors) in the holes at the bottom. Do not overtighten, as the force will crack the inner cuboid-shaped screw holders off and might damage your board.

comments.author: avalero

comments.text: Nice that you like it. Great idea! However, let me first finish this project up to a point at which it's generic enough to be worth imported into a library. The current code base is still too specific. I'm striving for a better separation of, and interface between the board description and the generator algorithm (called "case factory" in the code). For this, I want to introduce an abstract case factory base-class. The issue #1 on the bitbucket issue tracker explains another thing: If the generated case for some board isn't perfect, you might want to modify it. So currently you have two choices: modifying the board description or the case factory. But there are cases in which both isn't perfect. A good example is my most recent feature: wall support. It adds thicker walls (which go inside the case) where the walls would otherwise break very easily. It's an issue caused by the multiplication of the board description and the case factory, so not only one of them causes the issue. Not sure how to solve this nicely.
comments.author: avalero

comments.text:
:)
If you feel that adding some features to the OOML instead of including this directly on your project might help you can just make a pull resquest into the OOML git repo.
In any case, maybe it could help adding models of some standard things like the USB port, etc. to the OOML. I have made this for the Futaba, the IR Sensors, Battery of 9 volts, and others, and now it is quite easy to use them in my models.
comments.author: leemes

comments.text: I had a glance at the internal workings of OOML. Nicely designed architecture, by the way! The attach feature together with a library of standard ports will be a very good idea. My idea for the future is to let the user model the board which is then turned into a case by using it as a "negative" model. [The point about my project is to provide N board models and M case factories resulting in N*M possible case models.] However, some things are tricky. Such as the information on "how thick" a cable might be when plugged in. For example: the audio jacks on the Cubieboard don't "stand out" very much, so a big audio plug intersects with an only 2mm thick case design. This is why my "board description" includes an "outset" parameter which can be used to add a 45 deg diagonal cut along the outline of the port. Another "special case" are the screw holes which will be used by most case designs in a special way. Maybe we can put everything together in one nice and stable interface to describe some arbitrary electronic device?
comments.author: avalero

comments.text: That sounds great. I myself have no expertise with electronic boards, but as a "consumer" all you say sounds fantastic. I can help you with the OOML when you want. You can write me to my personal mail [email protected]

This hook goes on the slats of my bunk bed at my dorm, its useful to hang things off of and provides decent strength!

In my projects I often use microcontrollers which can be reprogrammed via ISP (in-circuit programming). If there is enough space, I usually intergrate a 6-pin ISP header, so that I can easily reload new firmware if required. However, sometimes, space is at a premium, which means I'll have to do without an ISP header. So the aim of this project was to generate a contact clip for in-circuit analyzing and programming of standard DIP ICs with 0.1" pin spacing, which allows me to reprogram microcontrollers and EEPROMs, and also debug my developments by analyzing the pin signals on the ICs directly. The pin contacts are made from standard pin headers. The bridge in the clip tweezers provides a spring to firmly clamp the contacts to the IC. Small gaps between the pins allow each pin arm to move individually, so that the contact force is spread to all pins evenly. The lead wires are fed from the inner rear of the clip through three holes to the outer front of the clip where they are soldered to the contacts headers. For printing, ABS is preferred in order for the plastic to provide the necessary elasticity. To allow printing despite of the (in printing position horizontal!) gaps between the pin arms, explicit supports are generated (shown red in the OpenScad drawing) which need to be cut away with a razor blade or a narrow knife after printing. As the arms should move freely against each other, sometimes it is necessary to "clean" the gaps with thin sandpaper. The holes for the pin headers and the wires are quite tight, so it may be necessary to cleanly redrill them after printing, for the pin header tips I got the best results with a 0.8mm drill bit. STL files for the standard 8-, 14-, 16-, 20- and 28-pin narrow DIP ICs as well as for 28- and 40-pin wide DIP ICs are provided. Other sizes can be easily obtained by modifying the fully parametrized SCAD file. Note that this project was not as easy to accomplish as I initially thought. The approach presented here is the result of several iterations, from first using simple wire loops, the switching to pin headers for the contacts and finally introducing the free swinging pin arms - the latter were definitely the key for getting good contacts on each pin every time...

The Dip-Clips were printed from 3mm ABS filament on my DIY Prusa i3 using a 0.4mm nozzle with 0.56mm extrusion width and 0.252 layer height.  
I print on a clear mirror without Kapton tape but thoroughly cleaned with acetone and double concentrated lemon juice.

All teeth of a Velociraptor mongoliensis in original size. They work pretty good with Form1. The base can be cut off.

https://skfb.ly/Dp8M The objects were printed at the Zurich University of the Arts in the digital fabrication module.
